Not everything that's worth eating is worth talking about
It's not the same day a leaf drops to the bottom of the water that it begins to rots
A suh mi duh mi ting: This is how I do my thing
A suh wi dweet: This is how we do it
A wah duh dem: What's wrong with them / What's their problem
A weh dem feel like: What the hell is their problem?
Accompong: A historic maroon village located in St. Elizabeth, Jamaica
Ackee: Ackee is one of the most popular fruits in Jamaica.  It is Jamaica's national fruit and also Jamaica's national dish combined with salt fish. Ackee is derived from the original name Ankye which comes from the Twi language of Ghana.
Agony: Slang term used to refer to the sensations felt during sex
It's time to go to sleep.
Ahoa: an exclamation similar to Oooh or Aaaah.
Aile: Pent up sexual tension or energy
Anansi: A character in Jamaican and African folklore. Anansi is a spider but often acts like a human being. Anansi is considered to be the god of all knowledge of stories and his tales are believed to have originated from the Ashanti people in Ghana
Awoah: Exclamation used to affirm or acknowledge a statement
Babylon system: Slang expression used to refer a corrupt government or organization that facilitates the rich  and exploits the poor
Back a Yard: Expression used to refer to one's home town or country, particularly in Jamaica. The literal translation is  Back at home'.
Backfoot: Slang term used as an expression of surprise
Backside: A Jamaican slang word which is used mostly when you are surprise.
Bad luck wus dan obeah: Bad luck is worse than witchcraft
bad lucky: Unlucky or in an unfortunate situation
Bag juice: A cheap beverage made of water and syrup that is sold in a small plastic bag.
bait up di thing: to set someone up for a downfall or cause disappointment or embarrassment
balm oil: A special oil used when conducting spiritual healings or other obeah rituals
Balm yard: A location where healing rituals are practice using obeah or other forms of dark magic
Bammy: A traditional Jamaican Flat round pancake-looking bread made from grated cassava from which the bitter juice has been extracted. The cassava is pressed downed to decrease thickness and then baked on both sides. It is normally served with fried fish or any other fried food.
Banana boat: Slang term for a boat or ship that is used to transport immigrants from the Caribbean to first world countries such as the England, United States or Canada. The ships were primarily used to transport bananas from the Caribbean but would also offer passage for anyone from Caribbean going to the returning country (America, England etc...) at a cheaper cost than normal passenger ships.
Batty wash: Stimulation of the anus with the tongue
Bawn back a cow: Expression used to refer to a very stupid or idiotic person. The literal translation is  born behind a cow'.
Bay rum: Aromatic alcohol rub used for medicinal purposes.
Bedroom Bully: A man or woman that is the primary initiator of sex in the bedroom. He/she controls sex and therefore controls the bedroom
Big hole gyal: Term used to refer to a female with a big/loose vagina
Big man ting: Slang term used to refer to a situation that is adult business; childish behavior is not acceptable
Big up yourself: give yourself a pat on the back
Bike back: The passenger seat of a motorcycle
bird bush: A place where lots of birds inhabit and is primarily used for bird hunting
bissy: A cola nut that it is used as a poison antidote or as medicine.
bitch up: To perform a task inadequately or crudely without attention to quality or detail
Blackbird says her child comes first.
Bleach: to go without sleep usually because of excessive partying or any other fun activity
Bleachaz: Slang expression used to refer to a black person who lightens their skin. The literal translation for  'bleachaz' is  bleacher
Bless: Whether it be 'bless', or a variation such as 'bless up' or 'blessings', or 'highly blessed', some Jamaicans generally greet each other in a way that says that they wish the other person peace, abundance and rest in all they do.
bless up: Bless up is used in Jamaica to mean, have a nice day, have a good day or have a blessed day.
Bloodseed: Mild curse word used when one is frighten
Blue Draws: A boiled pudding made from green bananas
Blue Mahoe: A species of flowering tree in the mallow family
Board man: Slang expression for a man that cannot get or satisfy a woman
Bogle: Popular dance by the dancehall icon of the same name Gerald Levy aka  bogle'.
Bolo Slush: A brown-looking stew with red peas,It is usually served with white rice or some large dumplings made of some kind of wheat flour.
bounce off: to share with someone for the purpose of getting feedback
Bow: Slang use to describe when someone performs oral sex; mostly on a woman.
Bowcat: Slang expression use to refer to someone who gives oral sex to a woman
BOX: A speaker box used for the amplification of reggae music. Boxes may be up to five feet tall, and are used both at parties and by record vendors to amplify music on the streets.
Box Food: Food sold in foamed clamshell take-out containers
Box Juice: Sweet Beverage sold in box containers
Bruk calabash, bring new one: Broke the calabash, bring a new one
bruk weh: to break away; to break loose
Bubble: A popular dance move done by women. This dance has strong sexual undertones and consist of a variety of hip and belly actions a woman does when she is dancing.
Buck up: To stumble or meet up with someone or something by chance.
Bulla: A small round cake made with molasses and flavored with banana or ginger. They are inexpensive and easy to make using molasses, flour and baking soda. They are typically eaten as a snack with cheese or avocado.
bumaye bumaya: An expression of greeting. Could also used in the context of telling someone you agree with them and others as well.
Bumbo-pussy-raasclaat: During an argument it is used to express feelings of anger or used when excited or within a conversation with friends.
Bumboclaat: One of the most popular swear words in Jamaica. Bumbo means bottom, claat is the Jamaican pronunciation of cloth. 'Bumboclaat' literally refers to either menstrual pads or toilet paper. it is mostly used as an exclamation of shock, surprise, anger, frustration or for any other intense emotions.This term is sometimes combine with other Jamaican expletives such as bloodclaat or p**syclaat. For example, bumbo-bloodclaat or bumbo-p**syclaat.Bumboclaat is actually a very vulgar swear word so you can get arrested for using it around police officers as well as dismissed from a class or  formal business place.
Bush Tea: A bunch of leaves, natural herbs, or grasses used for making tea, especially in the morning. The leaves are thrown into a boiling pot and steeped. The tea is strained off.
Busta: A popular soft drink in Jamaica
Butu: A person who has little or no social graces or manners. Being a butu is completely independent of your social class. Professor Rex Nettleford once correctly said, "A butu in a Benz is still a butu."
Caca faat: Slang term used as an expression of  extreme surprise (incredulous)
Cemetery: A girl whose had many abortion
Chat mi: To be talked badly about, or to be talked downly upon.Examples: Dem ah chat mi, yuh, wi, unuh etc.
Chicken merry, hawk deh near: Chicken is merry, a hawk is nearby
Chief's in the town, the con artist will prosper
Chiney Brush: Liquid which is brushed onto the penis to increase staying power. For those with erectile dysfunction
Chiney Shop: A store owned and operated by someone of Chinese ancestry
Cock it up: To have aggressive sex in a doggy-style position.
A c**k's mouth causes its death
Coco: Jamaican name for tannia and yautia. A staple food in the Caribbean, this tuber was originally imported from Polynesia (where it is known as taro) by the Portuguese. Cocos have a white chalky flesh. They may be left in the ground for considerable periods of time.
Coconut drops: A sweet treat made from diced coconut and sugar, and spiced with ginger.  At first the diced coconut is boiled and later the sugar and spice is added to the mixture. The mixture is then set to cool and harden on a flat surface.
Craven choke Puppy: Someone who wants everything but when it's giving to them, they can't handle it.
criss ting: slang for a hot chick(a woman).
Cut eye: An insulting gesture where one looks at another person from the corners of one's eyes, then turns one's eyes and gaze away in an exaggerated motion. This look is normally used on someone who is irritating, annoying or strongly disliked.
Daggering: A popular dance move done in Jamaican dancehall clubs. Daggering is where a man and woman are dancing in a sexually provocative manner (dry humping), which usually includes them simulating various sexual positions in an aggressive manner.
Dancehall: A fast paced style of Jamaican reggae which originated in the late 1970s. Dancehall is actually very different form traditional reggae as it is mostly made for dancing in the club (hence the name  dancehall').  Dancehall is mostly Dj-ing rather than singing; in which it typically involves multiple artistes dj-ing on a single riddim (e.g. guns and roses riddim). Some popular dancehall artistes are Beenie Man, Vybz Kartel, Mavado, Sean Paul, Bounty Killer and Shaba.
Dog with too much owner sleeps without bone
Dead left: Inheritance, mostly pieces of land and houses.
Deffaz: A very hard slap to the face that may cause temporary hearing loss to the victim
Deh pon a endz: Slang expression for saying that one has gone out (usually somewhere nice).
Deh yah pon di gully side: Slang expression used to state one is chilling at an impoverished or neglected area of an city
Di adda day: recently; just a few days ago
The older the moon the brighter it shines
Don't hang your basket higher than you can reach it
Don't throw away your stick before you cross the water
People with too much resources often end up with nothing in the end
drape up: to treat someone roughly along with holding them by  their clothes
Drop-pan: A gambling game of the lottery type in which tickets are bought, put into a pan, and the pan is dropped as a means of drawing the winning ticket
Dry land tourist: Slang expression for a Jamaican who has never left the island of Jamaica, but has begun to speak with a foreign accent, especially when he/she is around a tourist.
Dubplate: Derived from old school dancehall and reggae, dubplate may refer to either  exclusive unreleased tracks that only famous dj's have access to or the acetate disk that these unreleased tracks are cut unto.
Dukunu: Dukunu also known as  blue drawers', is a popular traditional food in Jamaica. It is a desert item made with flour, sugar, and some or all of the following in any combination: cassava, sweet potato or green bananas.
Duppy know who fi frighten: A ghost knows whom to frighten
Dutchie: a thick cooking pot made of iron that is normally used to cook meals on a wood fire.
Dutty wata can out fyah: Dirty water can put out a fire
Dutty wine: A sexually explicit Jamaican head dance where you move your legs in a butterfly motion and swing your head around.  It is mostly danced to a song by Tony Matterhorn titled  'Dutty Wine'.
One who does not heed to good advice always faces the repercussion of their own action(s)
Eat unda sheet: Slang use to describe the act of performing oral sex.
Empty bag cyaah tan up: An empty bag can't stand up
Enz: A place where someone lives or normally hangs out at.
Escovitch fish: A variation of ceviche; a sea food dish popular in the Latin American countries. The fish is fried then drench with a pickling sauce made from vinegar, pepper, onions and pimento.
Every hoe has their thicket of bushes
Everyday the bucket is brought to a well, the bottom will drop out eventually
Everyweh mi tun makka juk mi: Everywhere I turn, I'm poked by torns
Fatta: Nickname given to fat or obese male
Fire is at a mouse's tail, he thinks it's cool breeze
fish bowling: Smoking weed in a closed and small space, with the intent of not letting the smoke escape, to recycle the smoke in a space, as in a car.
Fisherman never says his fish stinks
Flex: Slang expression for making a move to go somewhere else or hanging out on the block.
Fluxy: Slang expression used to refer to anything that has undesirable characteristics (filthy, tacky, flimsy etc...).
Foot: In Jamaican Patois, the term  'foot' is used to refer to the legs, ankles or feet
Fowl fed at home isn't hard to catch
Frighten fi: give in or to give up
From mi yeye deh a mi knee: From my eyes were at my knees
Galliwasp: A harmless Jamaican lizard which is incorrectly believed to be poisonous.
Gaza Mi Seh: Slang expression used to state that  you support Vybz Kartel (a popular Jamaican entertainer) and his crew from the Portmore Empire(nicknamed  Gaza).  The literal translation is  'Gaza I say'
Goat is sweating but its long hair covers it
Good fowl says he's going to go the market, Sensei says he's going too
Grabba: Slang term for unprocessed tobacco leafs. It is normally mixed with marijuana when smoked
Greetings: An opening used to express a greeting or to answer a telephone, normally by Rastafarians
Gully Mi Seh: Slang expression used to state that you support Mavado (a popular Jamaican entertainer), but not is rival Vybz Kartel
Hand: In Jamaican Patois, the term  'hand' is used to refer to the hand or arm
Head top: Expression used to refer to the Crown of the head
It does no harm to show good manners to people
Idle Jubie: An idle or lazy young person.
If a fish comes from deep sea and tells you that it's deep, you can't say that's a lie
If you can't catch Quaco, you will catch his shirt
If you get hold of the blade, careful how you draw it
If you sleep with a dog, you will catch his fleas
If you want good, your nose will have to run
Irish Moss: A food drink made from the seaweed extract of Irish Moss.
It a shot: Slang expression used to describe something that is fabulous, fantastic, extraordinary etc...
Ital: Rastafarian slang used to describe food that is in its natural state; does that contain any artificial elements. This term is also used to describe food that is cooked with very little or no salt.
Jammin: to be singing, dancing and having a good time
Jeezam: Expression  use when one is surprise or amazed
Jelly: The soft flesh of a young coconut
Jerk pork: A famous Jamaican style of meat preparation which has originated from the Maroons and in common use throughout the island. Pimento wood is sometimes used to give it a special flavor.
Joe Grine: Slang expression used to refer to a man that has an affair with another man's wife/partner
June plum: A huge, greenish yellow plum. Originated in the South Pacific.
Kotch: Popular Jamaican dance done by females which involves movements of the hip, waist and leg in a sexual explicit manner. It is mostly danced to the song titled  'Kotch' by Jamaican Dancehall Duo, RDX
Kumina: An ancestor cult worship of Bantu origin. Very popular in Jamaica.
Learn to crawl before you walk
Leggings: When a man is tricked into thinking he's having sex with a woman, when in fact his penis is placed between her thighs.
Lick a shot: To open fire with a weapon (usually a gun).
Lignum Vitae: Native to tropical America, Lignum Vitae is one of the most useful trees in the world. It is the national flower of Jamaica.
Likkle canoe kip near shore: Little canoe is kept near shore
loud up di thing: To expose someone's dirty or bad business
Loud up di ting: Slang expression for gossiping/exposing someone's business
Macaroni: Used to describe a stupid person, particularly a bad driver usually carrying multiple unfortunate passengers. Someone is often called Macaroni after any type of automobile accident or if they are known to have had one or more crashes.
Man clown: A female that is strongly infatuated with a man and will do anything for him, even if he does not feel the same way
Do not offend people knowing full well they are in a better position to cause you harm
Maroons: Free hill dwellers whose forebears had either never known slavery or had successfully fled to the hills where they lived in free, self-governing communities
Massive: Group or collective of human beings
mawga cow a bull muma: A slim cow is mother to a bull.
Mento: Jamaican folk music, forerunner of calypso and reggae,now rarely performed
I came here to drink milk, I didn't come to count cows
Mi fyah cyaah quench: I can't stop, I will neva stop
I love you  with all of my heart
Mi need fi guh a hospital: I need to go to the hospital
I didn't come here to hear that a horse is dead and a cow is fat
Mi nuh deh pan nutten: Nothing is going on for me / I am not doing anything
Mi old but mi no cold: I am old but I am not cold
Mi old but mi nuh cold: I'm old but certainly not cold
I threw my corn but I didn't call any fowl
Mi waah fi bi wid yuh fi eva: I want to be with you forever
Mi wi lick yuh inna yuh face: I will hit you in your face
I would like some bottled water
My eyes are my market, you are my cocoa basket
Miss Lee: Expression used to refer to a person of Asian descent
Myal: A form of Caribbean white magic that became a religious cult. Myal practices  included the usage of herbal medicine and the capture and control of duppies (ghosts) for positive purposes. Many of its features have been incorporated into Kumina and other revival religions.
Nice up: To promote and foster a positive feeling.
Niceness: Greatness , very good , sweet or worthy
Everything that has sugar in it is not necessary sweet
Not everything good to eat is good to talk about
Nuh live nowhere: To have nothing or little, or not being in a comfortable or prosperous state because of poverty, no work etc. etc.
Nuh muss: Nuh muss is an expression used to show confidence in knowing something or the ability to do something .Expression of sertenty.
Nuh tek ugly mek laff: Don't take an ugly situation for laughter.
Don't trouble trouble until trouble troubles you
Nuttin nuh guh suh: It isn't like that / That's not true
Make use of your earliest opportunities and don't be delusional or so expectant of getting others that are not yet within your reach.
One Drop: A popular type of drum set playing used on countless reggae records. This style was popularized by Carlton Barrett and is characterized by which the bass drum is used only on the 3rd beat of every four, while beat one is left empty. Thus, the expected hit on beat one is "dropped," creating the one-drop effect.   Examples of songs using the one drop include "No Woman, No Cry" and "One Drop" by Bob Marley and The Wailers.
One Heart: An expression of unity, similar to the term  'one love'.
One Love: An expression of unity, one love refers to universal love and respect for all people, regardless of race, social status or any other defining characteristics.
One, one coco full basket: One by one cocoa can full a basket
ooo baan fi hengk yaan drawn: You cannot run away from your own destiny.
Patois: Jamaican Patois (also known as  'Patwa' or   'Patwah') is the language that is spoken by most Jamaicans. Jamaican Patois is a combination of an English based Creole language and West African based languages. Jamaican Creole came into existence as a medium for the slaves and their masters to communicate.
Patty: Popular Jamaican pastry that contains various fillings and spices such as beef, chicken or cheese that is baked in a golden yellow tinted flaky shell. In Jamaica, the patty is often paired with coco bread when being eaten.
Poppy show: Derived from the term  'puppet show', this term is often used to ridicule someone because they have done something idiotic.
Pum Pum Shorts: Extremely short shorts that barely covers a woman's buttocks and clearly shows the outline of her vagina (pum pum). These shorts are short enough to be panties.
Pum Pum tun down: YUh p**sy smell like jones beach
Punaani Printer: Shorts that are so tight and short that you can clearly see the vagina outline of the woman that is wearing it. The literal translation is  'p**sy printer'.
Cats and dogs do not have the same type of luck
Cat doesn't have any business in a dog's fight
Pussyclaat: Popular Jamaican curse word use to express strong anger or frustration
Pussyhole: Jamaican curse word use to refer to someone who is strongly disliked
Quashie come a town: Someone in a new and uncomfortable situation
Quatty buys trouble, hundred pounds can't pay for it
Quint: Slang expression used to refer to when a woman squeeze her inner vaginal muscles (specifically during sex).
Raas: Common Jamaican swear word, doesn't have an actual meaning
Rain a fall but dutty tuff: Rain is falling but the Earth is tough
Rasta man: a male that practices rastafarianism (may or may not wear a dreadlocks)
Rate: To like or admire someone or something
Reason: To have a conversation (to come to an understanding by having dialog).
Red: Term used to refer to a light skin black person
Rhaatid: Use to express mild surprise or irritation.
Rice and peas: Popular meal traditionally eaten on Sundays by Jamaicans. This dish is normally made with rice and kidney beans/ pigeon peas and served along with chicken, fish or beef.
Rizzla: A brand of rolling paper for joints/weed, in Kingston synonymous with rolling paper.
Rolling calf: A ghost that appears as a red eyed bull that hauls heavy chains behind it and haunts the earth at night
Rooks: To make love or have sexual intercourse
Rope In: Slang expression used to invite someone to join or participate in an activity.
Rub-a-dub: 'Rub-A-Dub' or 'Rub-A-Dub Style' is one the genres created during the passage between Reggae and Dancehall and was invented between the end of the 70s and the beginning of the 80s. The term "Rub-a-Dub" comes from a dance style where the man and woman rubs up very close together and grind their hips to the beat.
Rude Gyal: Derived from the term  'rude boy', this expression is normally used to refer to a rebellious or free spirited young woman
The same thing that pricks a sheep will prick a goat
Scornful dog eats a dirty pudding
See an blind hear an deaf: See but be blind to it; hear it but be deaf to it.
See an blind, Hear an def: See and blind, hear and deaf
seh feh: Similar in meaning to  'say something to me if you dare'. The literal translation is  'say feh'.
Sell off: Slang term for expression of approval, normally used to denote that something is very nice or very good. This term is also used to state that the desired effect of an activity has been achieved.
Shot yuh a bax: A quick slap (usually to the face)
To see me and come live with me are two different things
Skanking: A form of dancing originating in Jamaica, now most notably done in Ska/Reggae shows.
Skinout: Slang expression for when a female open her legs wide apart (either nude or scantily clad) which results in her exposing her vulva.
Slap: Slang term normally  used  by males interchangeable for the word  'sex'.
The more a cow grows, the more it's nostrils opens
Feel sorry for a hungry dog, then he turns around and bite you
Sound System: A huge mobile disco used to keep street parties in Jamaica.  A sound system normally consist of Djs, turntables and huge speakers.
Speaky-Spokey: When a Jamaican tries to speak in an American or British accent (but usually result in a poor attempt) .
On a cow's back yet cursing the cow
suru board: Board  use for cutting and rolling ganja
Tan Pon It Long: Slang expression  for saying that a man has strong sexual prowess; his sexual performance is spectacular and he is capable of having sex for a very long time. The literal translation of this term is  'stay on it long'.
tangalang: To pick up or carry something.
tegareg: someone of no class, uncouth, a hooligan
tek baaskit cyaary waata: Use a basket to carry water
Tek liberty Wid: Disrespect someone, to be rude to another.
Tek milk out a cawfe: Take milk out of a calf
Tekeisha: A greedy woman or exploiter; She is only interested in a man for is his money, even if she has just met him.
Tenement yard: Housing area that is generally poor or undeveloped.
Today is for me, tomorrow is for you
Tie: The act of trapping someone in a romantic relationship using a Jamaican dark magic called obeah.  This type of sorcery is practice mostly by women in order to keep their partners in a relationship because of financial or other perceived benefits.
Time longa dan rope: Time is longer than a rope
Trouble nuh set like rain: Trouble doesn't give signs like the rain
Tun up di ting: This is an exhortation to step up the tempo; improve on whatever you are doing
Tuntid: Use to express when someone is experiencing a dizzy spell
Twang: Slang term used to refer to when a Jamaican who grew up speaking heavy patois tries to talk in an American/British accent but ends up being a silly-sounding poor attempt because it is not natural.  Jamaicans who travel aboard for 3 weeks or less and return with an accent are normally teased with having a twang.
u zeemi: do you see what I'm saying?
u zimmi: Do you understand?, You know what I mean?
Wah bout yuh, Wah deh gwaan: How about you, How are you doing?
What drops off of the head, drops on the shoulder
What tastes good to a goat will later upset his stomach
Wah yuh a gwaan wid: What have you been up to?
Be where you will be appreciated and respected.
Those who really want something cannot get it, those who are always getting things do not want it
Wata more than flour: There is more water than flour
weh we a go do: What are we going to do?
When troubles catches up with you, a child's shirt fits you.
Wen coco ripe it muss buss: When a cocoa is ripe it will burst
Wen dawg a sleep nuh wake im: When a dog's sleeping, don't wake him
When a dog's flea bites you, you will have to scratch
Wen horse dead, cow get fat: When a horse dies, the cow gets fat
When water is thrown away it can't be picked up back
Wheel and come again: Try once more, come with a better story, or I remain unconvinced. This is generally used as an expression of disbelief.
We control things, things do not control us
Wine: A form of dancing normally done by women, which involves gyrating the mid-section of body , specifically the waist and hips. This is done in a sexual manner, either fast or slow and is mostly performed to West Indian music such as reggae, soca or calypso.
Yard bwoy: Slang expression for a person who is of Jamaican decent
Yuh a di luv a mi life: You are the love of my life
You can't plant corn and expect peas to be grown
You can't be sitting on a cow's back and be cursing the cow
You catch a cow by his horn but man by his word
If you play with a puppy, it will lick your face
Yuh salt: You are very bad lucky, I am so sorry for you or things are just not going your way.  'Mi Salt' is used when the person speaking is the one experiencing the bad luck.
Yuh si wah mi a seh: Do you see what I'm saying
Yuh too nuff: You are too full of yourself
Yuh undastan wah mi a seh: Do you understand what I'm saying?
Zeen: Slang expression used when one is in agreement with something that was said, similar to ok, yeah or yes.
Zinc fence: Old corrugated iron sheets that are normally used as fencing material in poor urban areas in Jamaica. They are normally associated with poor housing and poverty.
